Posts.Content: scannon82 wrote: Hi all I would love some advice please from people with a little more knowledge that me. To start, my mother's mother (my grandmother) died of breast cancer aged around 50, and her sister (my grandmother's sister) also died of it. My mother had it too at around 55. She is now 64 and doing well. My mother was tested for the gene, and does not carry it. Whilst this is clearly good news, what I want to know is, does this mean that my sister and I are still at high risk of getting it, just not AS high risk? Or does my mum not carrying the gene mean that our risk has gone back down to that of someone whose mother/grandmother doesn't have it? I am worried about this for obvious reasons, but even more so recently as I have been diagnosed with endometriosis. To manage the symptoms, my doctor has suggested going on the pill. I am 34 and have never been on the pill before, and was happy to do so until... I discovered through the dangers of Googling that it can increase the risk of breast cancer. According to some studies, everyone is at increased risk whilst they take it and for 10 year after, but other studies state that you're only at risk if you're already at risk (I.e family history, gene etc). So what I want to know is, am I already at risk? Despite that my mum doesn't carry the gene? Or am I at normal risk, in which case it might be OK to take the pill? I am really upset as I clearly don't want to increase my risk, but I need to manage my endometriosis and stop it getting worse. I feel like I can't win. Any help much much much appreciated.
